p: Owing to an increase in seasonal temperature by approximately 13%, the irrigated and high‐rainfall calorie yields would increase by 1%–3% and 19%–23% with fixed and elevated CO 2, respectively, in Western Europe, but only by 13% in the latter case in France. Importantly, water‐limited yields in southern France decreased by 5% when CO 2 effect is not considered. Yet, elevated CO 2 has the potential to offset the negative effects, leading to an overall increase by 4% (Figure 3b). In general, maize and other summer crops would benefit from alleviated low temperature limitations in the wetter and cooler parts of Western Europe, while winter crops and tubers will benefit from elevated CO 2. Winter cereals would be affected negatively without elevated CO 2 fertilization (Text S2, also Figure S2 and S10 in Supporting Information S1).
